linkTarget.anchoringText: This project started with acquiring some special openhole log data, including ADT (Advanced Dielectric Tool), MSIP (Sonic Scanner) and XPT (Xpress Pressure Tool) data (see Figure 1).

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Special logs: ADT (Water saturation), MSIP (Sonic scanner) and XPT (Xpress pressure tool)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Special logs: ADT (Water saturation), MSIP (Sonic scanner) and XPT (Xpress pressure tool)

linkTarget.anchoringText: From Figure 2 to Figure 6, some of the test results that were used to calibrate the different models used in this study, including petrophysics, rock properties, and perforation design, are shown.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Laboratory test results: Formation Resistivity Index and Factor

formatted-caption.caption-text: Laboratory test results: Formation Resistivity Index and Factor

linkTarget.anchoringText: From Figure 2 to Figure 6, some of the test results that were used to calibrate the different models used in this study, including petrophysics, rock properties, and perforation design, are shown.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Laboratory test results: Capillary Pressure and Susceptibility to Flood Water

formatted-caption.caption-text: Laboratory test results: Capillary Pressure and Susceptibility to Flood Water

linkTarget.anchoringText: From Figure 2 to Figure 6, some of the test results that were used to calibrate the different models used in this study, including petrophysics, rock properties, and perforation design, are shown.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Laboratory test results: Pore size distribution

formatted-caption.caption-text: Laboratory test results: Pore size distribution

linkTarget.anchoringText: From Figure 2 to Figure 6, some of the test results that were used to calibrate the different models used in this study, including petrophysics, rock properties, and perforation design, are shown.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Laboratory test results: Pore volume compressibility

formatted-caption.caption-text: Laboratory test results: Pore volume compressibility

linkTarget.anchoringText: From Figure 2 to Figure 6, some of the test results that were used to calibrate the different models used in this study, including petrophysics, rock properties, and perforation design, are shown.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Laboratory test results: Triaxial compressive tests

formatted-caption.caption-text: Laboratory test results: Triaxial compressive tests

linkTarget.anchoringText: The petrophysical model also showed the invasion radius by processing and inverting resistivity data taken from the electrical logs. The petrophysical model of the Apaika A-011 well is shown in Figure 7.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Petrophysics and invasion zone determined for the Apaika A-011 well in the M1 Reservoir

formatted-caption.caption-text: Petrophysics and invasion zone determined for the Apaika A-011 well in the M1 Reservoir

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 8 shows the rock properties and their calibration.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Profile and calibration of mechanical properties of the rock. M1 Reservoir

formatted-caption.caption-text: Profile and calibration of mechanical properties of the rock. M1 Reservoir

linkTarget.anchoringText: The preferential direction of minimum horizontal stress was determined in the direction of the 30° ± 10° azimuth, as shown in Figure 9.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Horizontal stress direction in the Apaika field

formatted-caption.caption-text: Horizontal stress direction in the Apaika field

linkTarget.anchoringText: Consequently, average stress magnitudes from a neighboring field (e.g. Eden Yuturi) were used, assuming a similar behavior to determine the magnitude of horizontal stresses in the Apaika A-011 well; and to validate both the rock properties and the stresses, a wellbore stability analysis was done to represent the borehole behavior during drilling. Figure 10 shows the wellbore stability analysis.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Wellbore stability: Stress field and rock properties validation in Apaika A-011

formatted-caption.caption-text: Wellbore stability: Stress field and rock properties validation in Apaika A-011

linkTarget.anchoringText: Finally, a system with the following characteristics was chosen: PowerJet Nova 4512, HMX, 21.0 g, OD 4.5", 135/45° Phasing, 12 spf, resulting in an average penetration of 21.21" with an average rock diameter of 1.02". Figure 11 shows the advanced perforating design.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Advanced perforating design

formatted-caption.caption-text: Advanced perforating design

linkTarget.anchoringText: Average particle size distribution showed a D50 of 420 μm, classifying it as a medium grain sandstone; however, there is significant fine-grain distribution including clays, with a D90 of 81 μm (see Figure 12).

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Particle size distribution of M1 Sandstone in Apaika A-002

formatted-caption.caption-text: Particle size distribution of M1 Sandstone in Apaika A-002

linkTarget.anchoringText: Using the M1 Sandstone core analyses, it was described as a clean, non-calcareous, inorganic, dark brown, non-graded, medium to coarse grain, well-sorted, moderately cemented, high porosity sandstone without the presence of fossils. (Figure 13).

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: M1 Sandstone facies (core Apaika A-002 well)

formatted-caption.caption-text: M1 Sandstone facies (core Apaika A-002 well)

linkTarget.anchoringText: To determine critical drawdown (when the first grain of sand is produced), several simulations were performed in Sand Management Advisor based on rock properties, the stress field, reservoir pressure, perforation diameters and grain size (see Figure 14).

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Data input for critical drawdown pressure analysis

formatted-caption.caption-text: Data input for critical drawdown pressure analysis

linkTarget.anchoringText: Through these simulations the sanding window was identified by analyzing the sensitivity of the variables and uncertainty (see Figure 15 and Figure 16).

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Sanding window: Sensitivity analysis for grain size

formatted-caption.caption-text: Sanding window: Sensitivity analysis for grain size

linkTarget.anchoringText: Through these simulations the sanding window was identified by analyzing the sensitivity of the variables and uncertainty (see Figure 15 and Figure 16).

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Sanding window: Uncertainty analysis for M1 Reservoir in the Apaika A-011 well

formatted-caption.caption-text: Sanding window: Uncertainty analysis for M1 Reservoir in the Apaika A-011 well

linkTarget.anchoringText: This study has certain limitations that allowed for a certainty of 70% to 75% (70.6% of known fixed variables, 17.6% of known unfixed variables, and 11.8% of unknown variables). Main limitations are shown in Figure 17

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: Sanding model reliability

formatted-caption.caption-text: Sanding model reliability

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 18 shows production from the Apaika A-011 well, and Figure 19 shows the particle size analysis done to a sample of the sand taken from the well during workover operations.

image-wrap.label: Figure 18
image-wrap.caption: Production in the Apaika A-011 well

formatted-caption.caption-text: Production in the Apaika A-011 well

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 18 shows production from the Apaika A-011 well, and Figure 19 shows the particle size analysis done to a sample of the sand taken from the well during workover operations.

image-wrap.label: Figure 19
image-wrap.caption: Granulometry of produced sand, Apaika A-011 well

formatted-caption.caption-text: Granulometry of produced sand, Apaika A-011 well

linkTarget.anchoringText: In Figure 20 the oilfields that could apply this kind of analysis are shown.

image-wrap.label: Figure 20
image-wrap.caption: Presence of M1 Sandstone in Ecuador’s Oriente Basin
